org.openliberty.openaz.pep
Class PepRequestFactoryImpl

java.lang.Object
  org.openliberty.openaz.pep.PepRequestFactoryImpl
All Implemented Interfaces:
PepRequestFactory
public class PepRequestFactoryImpl
extends java.lang.Object
implements PepRequestFactory

The PepRequestFactoryImpl is an implementation class of the OpenAz project that implements the PepRequestFactory interface.

The primary purpose of this class and the others in this package and the classes in the companion org.openliberty.openaz.pdp package and subpackages is to provide a reference implementation for the test programs in test to use in conjunction with demonstrating the use of the overall "PepApi" (org.openliberty.openaz.azapi.pep interfaces and the "AzApi" (org.openliberty.openaz.azapi) interfaces.

Please reference the javadoc in PepRequestFactory for further information as to the general purpose of this class and the methods in it. The javadoc in this class and package will focus on the specific objectives of this reference implementation and how it supports the interface methods and any particular specifics regarding the OpenAz AzApi implementation that it is intended to utilize.

PepRequestFactory is the main entry point for building Policy Enforcement Point (PEP) capabilities that can be utilized by applications and containers.

The main use of this factory class is to enable clients to easily submit the objects that contain information that is expected to be used in Security Policy evaluation to the authorization system. There are two major steps that need to be taken to enable requests to be submitted:

  • First an authorization service reference must be provided to the factory that it can link to the request objects that it will instantiate.
    • Instantiate the PepRequestFactory by obtaining a registered instance of AzService. (Note: see TestStyles.setUpAzService() for an example of how to register service implementations.
             AzService azService = 
                AzServiceFactory.getAzService();
       PepRequestFactory pep = 
        (PepRequestFactory)new PepRequestFactoryImpl(CONTAINER,azService);
  • To enable this capability there are six PepRequest instance creation methods provided as specified by the PepRequestFactory interface: 
     newPepRequest(String, String, String)
 newPepRequest(Object, Object, Object)
 newPepRequest(Object, Object, Object, Object)
 newBulkPepRequest(Object, List, Object)
 newBulkPepRequest(Object, List, List, Object)
 newQueryPepRequest(Object, Object, String, PepRequestQueryType)

Author:
Josh Bregman, Rich Levinson, Prateek Mishra

Create a PepRequest using any set of objects for the Subject, Action, Resource, Environment entities.

Note: for this PepRequest to work, the appropriate JavaObjectMapper classes must be configured and set using RequestAttributesFactoryImpl.setMappers(List)

                             throws PepException
Create a PepRequest using objects, where a list of n action objects and a corresponding list of n resource objects are provided to represent n resource-action pairs. A decision for each resource-action pair will be returned, when PepRequest.decide() is invoked.

Specified by:
newBulkPepRequest in interface PepRequestFactory

resourceObjects - a list of length n, of resourceObj Objects representing the Resources ex: String (file) or File
environmentObj - Object representing the Environment ex: Map containing attributes name and values
Returns:
a PepRequest populated with mapped Attributes

newQueryPepRequest

public PepRequest newQueryPepRequest(java.lang.Object subjectObj,
                                     java.lang.Object environmentObj,
                                     java.lang.String scope,
                                     PepRequestQueryType queryType)
                              throws PepException
Create a PepRequest using subject and environment objects, plus a "scope" String that represents a PDP policy-specific resource representation. When the PepRequest.decide() method is invoked, based on queryType it will return either 
                - a list of Allowed ResourceAction pairs within scope
                - a list of Denied ResourceAction pairs within scope
                - or a list of full detailed results for all 
                        ResourceAction pairs within scope

Specified by:
newQueryPepRequest in interface PepRequestFactory
Parameters:
subjectObj -
environmentObj -
scope - a string containing a PDP policy-specific resource representation
queryType - an enum containing a choice of allowed, denied, or full/verbose
Returns:
a PepRequest populated with info mapper from the params
Throws:
PepException

newPEPRequest

protected PepRequest newPEPRequest(PepRequestOperation operation)
Internal factory method used by all the public methods to call into the actual PepRequestImpl constructor.

Note to developers: This method makes the actual call to PepRequestImpl.PepRequestImpl(AzRequestContext, PepRequestFactory, PepRequestOperation).

Note that the above constructor is where the PepApi objects, which are contained in this PepRequestFactoryImpl class are related to the AzApi objects thru the AzRequestContext handle obtained from the AzApi AzService implementation.

The newPepRequest methods continue on return from obtaining the underlying PDP AzApi AzRequestContext, and are able to invoke the mappers to translate the local objects to the AzApi objects.

Note also, that if this PepApi impl is used for guidance for implementing a direct PepApi-PDP interface, that the modules here that bridge to AzApi would likely have corresponding modules to bridge to the specific PDP API.

Note also, that the long term goal of PepApi/AzApi is to use AzApi as a common set of PDP request/response objects that any PDP can map from and any PEP can map to, which will provide a common interoperability layer.

Note also, that it is also recognized that direct links from PepApi to PDP can provide improved performance, so, in conjunction with proper configuration, it should be possible to provide both full interoperability and high performance. For full flexibility for any request to go to any pdp at any time, it is likely the common interface will be required, however, if there are stable configurations and expected policy processing sequences, then configuration can likely expose sections where direct links can be used with little or no sacrifice of interoperability.

Parameters:
operation -
Returns:
a PepRequest with initial AzEntity objects ready to be populated
